Compliance Audits, PHA studies, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, in addition to routine PSM/RMP Committee Meetings have generated recommendations to improve safety and compliance at the facility.  These include enhancing employee training policies, revising standard operating procedures, improving documentation and recordkeeping, and updating preventative maintenance policies, as well as ammonia equipment repairs.

Synear Foods representatives also provide guidance and assistance for the facility personnel to ensure outstanding issues are resolved, and that the facility remains in compliance.  Synear Foods USA also plans to improve safety as follows:
 
 --  Continued involvement of refrigeration and safety personnel in the ongoing development and implementation of the risk management policies.

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

EPA’s RMP regulation defines “accident” as the following: 

“The release must be from a covered process and involve a regulated substance held above its threshold quantity in the process. The release must have caused at least one of the following: 

--  On-site deaths, injuries, or significant property damage (§68.42(a)); or
--  Known offsite deaths, injuries, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place (§68.42(a)).”

An investigation into the facility’s accident history revealed that there have been no releases of ammonia over the past five years (October 2017 – October 2022) that meet the EPA reporting criteria for the Five-Year Accident History as specified above.  In addition, there have been no injuries resulting from a release of ammonia.

Continued safety improvement for the ammonia refrigeration system is a top priority for Synear Foods USA.  The management plan, internal audits, Process Hazard Analysis studies, as well as our prevention programs are monitored and updated as appropriate to ensure that all elements of our PSM/RMP policy remain accurate and complete.


EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM  

An emergency planning and response policy has been developed at the Synear Foods USA facility and is maintained by the EHS + HR departments.  It is based on Cal-OSHA’s requirements for Emergency Action Plan (CCR Title 8, Section 3220).  The Emergency Action Plan is detailed in the Emergency Planning & Response section of the PSM/RMP document which is maintained by the EHS Manager and the HR Manager at the facility.

This program contains procedures detailing how the facility will respond to acc

ble parties at the plant for each element of the facility’s PSM / RMP program.  Compliance Audits are also conducted every 3 years that can identify potential compliance issues and recommend actions to achieve full compliance.

In the event of an ammonia release, the emergency response plan is coordinated with the local emergency planning commission (LEPC) and the local fire house – City of Los Angeles Fire Department Station 96.  The ultimate goal for Synear Foods USA’s PSM/RMP plan is to prevent accidental releases of ammonia, injuries / illnesses, and to avoid adverse impacts to the environment.  These programs enable our facility to operate a refrigeration system safely because they are based on the rules, procedures, and guidelines that govern the ammonia refrigeration system, as well as the broader ammonia refrigeration industry throughout the country.

The Synear Foods USA ammonia refrigeration system has many safety features.  Much of the safety of the system is inherent in the policies and procedures that govern the operation of the system.  The Synear Foods USA facility, including the ammonia system, was designed and constructed in accordance with the recognized industry codes and standards, which specifically outline requirements for the design and operation of ammonia refrigeration systems.  Safety features include ammonia leak detectors in the machinery room and production areas, microprocessor controlled compressors with automatic safety cutouts, ASME certified pressure vessels, and emergency stop controls.  The majority of the ammonia inventory is centrally located in the machine room vessels and equipment.  All pressure-rated vessels are equipped with mechanical pressure relief valves that automatically engage in case of a high pressure situation and vent to a water diffusion tank that is available to neutralize high pressure ammonia.

Ammonia refrigeration systems do not experience any chemical reactions or internal corrosion.  The only composition

acility operates continuously based on production and temperature demands.  The compressors and condensers cycle on and off to address system heat load demands during operation.  The machinery room houses the compressors, recirculator and accumulator vessels, and auxiliary components, while the condensers and heat exchangers are located on the roof.  Some ammonia equipment is located in production areas.

Ammonia is used as the primary refrigerant, which means it is used as a vehicle to move heat from product, cold storage zones, and secondary coolants (glycol) to the outside atmosphere.  When heat is absorbed by the liquid ammonia, it vaporizes (changes phase), and is then compressed by the compressors.  The resulting high pressure ammonia vapor is routed to the condensers, where fans and sprayed water are used to reject latent heat in the ammonia vapor, causing it to condense to a liquid.

Multiple auxiliary systems are in place to support the operational and safety requirements of the ammonia system including:  ammonia leak detection, auto purger to remove non-condensible gasses, pressure relief system, refrigeration control system, and a water diffusion tank.


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS

To deal with the risks involved with ammonia refrigeration, policies and programs have been developed for the Synear Foods USA facility to limit the risks of an accidental ammonia release and/or minimize the consequences of a significant release, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents.

Programs developed for the PSM/RMP programs include employee participation, process safety information, process hazard analysis, pre-startup safety review, standard operating procedures, training, management of change, mechanical integrity, hot work permit, contractor management, and incident investigation.  To help coordinate the various elements of the program, a management system has been established that defines responsi

ng the risks associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.


STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE

The Synear Foods USA – Chatsworth facility was re-commissioned in the Summer of 2017 following a change in ownership.  The facility is located approximately 2 miles south of State Highway 118 and approximately 0.4 miles east of Topanga Canyon Boulevard (SR-27).  The facility is approximately 8 acres in size.

Synear Foods USA manufactures, packages, and distributes Chinese food products and uses the anhydrous ammonia refrigeration system (closed-loop process) for product freezing, cold storage logistics operations, and process fluid (i.e., glycol) cooling.  The maximum intended inventory of ammonia at the facility is approximately 33,000 pounds.

The accidental release prevention program starts with good operating and manufacturing practices.  All ammonia process equipment, piping, and valves are inspected and maintained on a regular schedule in accordance with manufacturer and industry recommendations.

For example, all compressors are routinely inspected for oil leaks, pressure and temperature gauge calibrations, vibration analysis, oil pressure, and amp reading for motors;  alignment of compressor motors and bearings, filter changes, vibration readings are performed every 6 months on compressor motors;  the condensers are inspected weekly (this includes checking and cleaning nozzles and strainers), motors are greased, fans are checked for cracks, and piping is inspected for leaks;  low and intermediate pressure receiver oil pots are drained, pump bearing wear is monitored;  visual inspection for equipment and vessel operating conditions, piping and valves are assessed for leaks, integrity, and other potential abnormalities on daily basis;  pressure relief valves are replaced on a five year frequency.  Ammonia leak detectors are calibrated semi-annually and trigger local audible and visual alarms for plant personnel.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Synear Foods USA recognizes the facility’s responsibility in protecting the public, its employees, the environment, equipment, and property.  Synear Foods USA is strongly committed to employee, public and environmental safety.  This commitment is reflected in a comprehensive accidental release prevention program.  This program addresses the design, installation, operation, maintenance, and employee training associated with the ammonia refrigeration equipment at the Synear Foods USA in Chatsworth, California.

It is Synear Foods USA’s policy to ensure that controls are in place to limit the risks of potential ammonia releases.  To accomplish the company’s goal in controlling accidental losses, the facility has established safety programs that enable plant personnel to: maximize safety performance, reduce risks of handling ammonia and other potentially hazardous substances, and prepare plant personnel to address emergency situations as they might arise.

The Chatsworth facility draws from decades of internal experience and expertise, as well as resources of external consultants, to ensure that the appropriate mitigation measures have been identified and are implemented.  The commitment to safety shows in the minimal accident history at the facility.

One of the activities associated with the plant’s safety program has been the development and implementation of accidental release prevention and emergency response programs which are designed to comply with OSHA’s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard (Process Safety Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals, 29 CFR 1910.119), and EPA’s Risk Management Program (RM program) regulation (Risk Management Programs for Chemical Accidental Release Prevention, 40 CFR Part 68).
